Posts.Content: irish22 wrote: I am seriously considering asking for anti anxiety meds or anti depressents or pretty much anything. My dad won't go back home and when I try to make him he gives me a guilt trip about how we're all horrible children, we all lie and steal from him. I can't deal with his craziness anymore, his hypochondria and him whining about how much longer do I have to take chemo because it's making me lazy and rude. I know this sounds awful but I can't. He clearly is suffering from some sort of serious mental issue and he refuses to admit it and seek help for it, he won't talk to the doctor about it and prefers to make us all suffer because of it. I tried to talk to him calmly about it, I tried being mean about it, I've tried yelling and screaming about it, I even called his doctor and told him he's gone crazy. He fakes major health issues all the time. He came home a few weeks ago and told me he was in liver, kidney and gallbladder failure (yes, gallbladder failure). There was nothing the doctors could do so they sent him home, of course 2 days later he was fine. Two weeks ago he called everyone he knew before his routine colonoscopy to tell them the doctors were sure he had colon cancer. He lies to my siblings and me to start fights between us, he accuses the mailman of opening his mail, he says my brother and I are stealing money from him and accuses me of hiding his bank statements. I'm still working 40 hours while doing chemo and try to get in a nap if i can, when I do that he tells me I'm being lazy and wakes me up repeatedly until I just get up. He cooks meals that are nothing but fried food (which I'm not a big fan of plus my appetite just isn't always there) and then screams about how ungrateful I am if I don't eat them. Any food I buy he throws away and tells me it molded, even my poptarts molded in two days! He keeps making weird pureed veggie drinks and told me it's curing his diabetes, he isn't diabetic. Since he refuses help my brother has tried telling him he needs to go home that he's stressing me out to much and he's stressing him out too. He says we just want to get rid of him and not to worry when he leaves he won't bother us ever again. I know there is something seriously wrong and try to remind myself of this but he just pushes and pushes and then when I flip out finally somehow it is all my fault and I'm an awful person. I can't do it anymore. He's letting me live in his vacation house up here for the time being which he usually uses for a couple of months a year and thats it and I'm very grateful for that because money has been tight but it's not worth it and I'm going to have to move soon. The thought of moving and more bills is stressing me out even more. I miss my sister who lives out of state. While my brother occasionally drives me to an appt hes quickly moving into denile, he even booked a vacation the week of my surgery and said he didn't think it was a big deal, apparently I'll be going to that alone too. I'm sick of going to appts and chemo alone, I'm sick of spending hours on the train to ride to chicago for my appts and tx, I'm sick of listening to my friends whine about how much their lives suck (trade ya). In the past 3 weeks neuropathy has set in on my hands and feet, my skin is just a mess from taxol toxicity as the NP said and chemo brain make me feel like a zombie. Yesterday a coworker walked up to me infront of everyone and asked if I heard that a girl my age from the town over died of cancer the other day and i spent my lunch break crying in my car. I have no idea what to do, part of me wants to say eff it and hop on a plane and live out my time on a beach sipping mixed drinks. The other part of me keeps trying to remind myself this is just as hard on them as it is on me. And as for my dad he's gonna be lucky if I don't tie his ass up and leave him in a wheelbarrel outside the psych hospital door. I'm at a loss emotionally. I know this rant was long and kind of whinning too, sorry, but I do thank you from the bottom of my heart for reading it. Any suggestions on good mood meds would be appreciated, I'm tempted to go back to my college days of smoking weed.    Keep Calm and Carry On Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 1, 17/34 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 09:20PM - edited May 24, 2011 09:22PM by irish22 New Reality, the life long treatment has been the hardest thing for me to accept. I can't seem to wrap my mind around the fact that there will never be an end, I will never hit a point where I won't have to recieve treatment. I also hate the fact that life long treatment is hard to explain to people who don't understand stage IV breast cancer. If one more person tells me "(insert BC survivor they know or Christina Applegates name) had a masectomy X number of years ago and they're fine! They didnt have to be on chemo forever so I'm sure you won't!" I will punch them in the ribs. I want to reply: "Well remember Elizabeth Edwards? Thats the type I have."  On the other end of the spectrum tho I guess we are blessed that there are treatments that can extend our time, some cancers once they're stage IV theres nothing that can be done. While our prognosis sometimes seems grim we see so many people here who are living 5, 7, 18 years! I never thought I'd say I'd be greatful if I can live to see 30 but I am grateful that if I can put up with all the crappy meds, scans, appointments and SEs I at least get a chance at it.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 08:51PM irish22 wrote: Rosasmommy I am 26 with mets from the get go. I never wanted a child of my own, I was happy being the fun "aunt" to my nieces and friends kids, to spoil them with candy and presents and love and send them home for the night. :-) Then when I was suddenly told I couldn't have chilldren and I was so upset by this, I guess just losing the independance of making those decisions for yourself is often what hurts the most. I can be content loving the little ones in my life that aren't mine and my fur baby doggy but I too have an overwhelming sense of how differently I would have done things and that the plans I had for my future slipped through my fingers so suddenly. I had purchased a plane ticked two weeks before my dx to go work in the Mother Teresa hospice for the dying women of Kolkata (Calcutta) in Sept '11, a dream I've always had. Paperwork filed, apartment set up and everything. Now I'll be in surgery in September. How strange our lives are. And I definatley wouldn't hae stayed with the same guy for the last four years, I knew we'd never marry but I cared about him and it was comfortable. I wish I'd found the one, I wish I'd traveled more instead of working all the time, I wish I'd actually finished school instead of quitting because I was bored. Oh, but you and I will find a way to be content in this life and make big waves despite this disease. Here's to hoping it won't take over our bodies and never letting it destroy our spirits!

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 07:34PM irish22 wrote: I did 6 months of taxol coupled with avastin. It wasn't the worst, but certainley not a walk in the park. I did mine on Wednesdays and weekends were usually my worst, by Saturday afternoon I was a zombie. I found taxols symptoms to up a little bit each week. First 3 weeks or so felt decent, then each week seemed to be a litte more taxing on me. I felt like I had the flu all the time and was in a haze. I recommend sucking on lemon heads for the metal mouth you'll get and using a good moisturizer for dry skin, report any neuropathy immediatley ( i was lucky, I didn't get any until my 5th month and even now just have the smallest amount in my heals), drink LOTS of water and get a good extra soft tooth brush and keep on top of your oral health ( i noticed my gums receded considerably). I also had horrible nail issues, one of the ladys on here told me to soak them in listerine and it took care of it quickly. I was told no to dental work while on chemo d/t blood count issues, infection risk and slow healing. With all that being said I still continued to work full time and even some overtime a couple of weeks the entire time I was on taxol and even started taking zumba classes halfway through my regime. Good luck!

Posts.Content: irish22 wrote: So I finally found a surgeon to remove my breast tumor. I admit, she's probably only doing it out of guilt and sympathy, because originally she didn't want to. She kept telling me that there was no concrete proof it made any difference but I was distraught and clutching articles I had printed that she had written herself about studies and theories on improved survival time in stage IV women who opted for surgery. Thanks rkt for sending me those articles by the way. Anyway that was back in December. Last week I got my BRCA and P53 genetic results and all were negative, so as we agreed if they were negative I would compromise with her for the less invasive lumpectomy with lymph node dissection and radiation. I also have to have no clotting activity and no progression in the mean time. My scans last week were clear besides sclerosed (sp?) bone mets on my spine so I'm thinking surgery is on. My surgery is scheduled for March 26 at MDA so I need to get to making my mind up about radiation. I am scared to death of it. I worked in home health and hospice for a few years and saw some awful breast radiation. I'm also scared that it could cause a secondary cancer (my grandpa got bladder cancer from the radiation for his prostate cancer) or it can activate some met cells that are currently just chilling out. I was wondering what all you ladies think about radiation after stage IV diagnosis? I feel like I've fought so hard to get this surgery I may be doing myself a disservice for not going all the way with the follow up but I also feel like I'm doing so well pysically right now I might be inviting trouble. Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2011 08:45PM irish22 wrote: I talked to the NP at my work. She said that Epogen has been shown to increase tumor progression as well as have a higher incidense of fatal thrombotic reactions in metastatic bc patients. The use of epogen is discouraged and should be avoided in patients where the goal is cure and used carefully in metastic patients. If needed for a co-morbid condition (ie. renal disease) then the dosage decision is left to the oncologist who bases the decision off of current tx, tumor markers, etc. She said that the warning put out by the drug manufacturer themselves says epogen should only be used in breast cancer patients who are currently recieving chemotherapy. I'm anxious to hear what your onc says, how do they determine that a tx is or is not working when they are basically feeding the cancer at the same time?

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 03:54PM irish22 wrote: Hi Kokonut, I just wanted to tell you how sorry I am you have to be on these boards but welcome anyways. You will find a great source of support and infomation here. I know how scary it is to have a pending stage IV diagnosis so I wanted to offer some advice. One DO NOT google statistics, they are worthless and often manipulated on many sites to support their views and theories. They also don't break down factors such as people who were diagnosed at the point that treatment was not an option or people that chose no treatment. Wait  until you have all the facts of your cancer before reasearching, things such as your grade and your hormonal status. Otherwise you will scare and overwhelm yourself. Second do not count yourself out if you are diagnosed stage IV, even if it is mets on your spine. Bone scans are not definative and they can pick up on things that aren't there and leave out things that are. Ask for a spinal MRI to be sure. Bone mets are considered the "best" mets to have if you have them, they are often easily manageable and for longer periods of time. I was diagnosed with stage IV with mets to my spine last year and I am doing great and have no symptoms. If it wasn't for post chemo troll hair I doubt anyone could tell I have cancer. Third Occult tumors do happen, tho rare, but you will be no better or worse off as anyone else with a primary intact tumor of the same grade. Shortly after I was diagnosed I got a new patient at the clinic I work at who had an occult breast cancer. Hers was found when they thought she had cellulitis in her arm but it turned out to be skin mets. She responded well to treatment but sadly passed in a car accident a few months ago. I have also read that chemo works better on people with lower tumor burden, with no main tumor to fight it can focus on wiping out all the cancerous nodes and stray cells anywhere else.   Good luck to you, prayers for comfort and peace to you during this difficult time. <3

Posts.Content: irish22 wrote: Hi, I'm 26 and will be having my first biopsy done on Tuesday of both my lump and an axilla lymph node. About 5 months ago I developed a lump under my areola region. For the next two months the lump grew some, then about 3 months ago I started noticing changes in my breast appearence. I decided I'd keep an eye on it but wasn't really concerned. The only breast cancer history I have is an aunt on my dads side diagnosed in her 60's and I'm under 30. Then it seems like before I knew it my nipple had become flattened and the skin around it kind of lumpy and I'd developed a flaky appearence on my nipple. I also started having an intermittent burning sensation near the lump and spreading to the underside of my breast. The lump itself is hard as a rock but does not hurt at all, but the tissue around it seems irritated. I finally went to  my gp to have it looked at on Tuesday. She called the breast specialist and they said to ultrasound it and call me in a couple of days after that with my result. At my ultrasound the tech came in and checked it out then told me she had to get the radiologist. The Dr. came in and checked the lump and lymph nodes under my arm. She told me i have a 3cm solid mass and thickening of my lymph node walls and something about blood flow to the cortexs of my lymph nodes. She let me see the lump on the ultrasound and you could see where it was pulling at surrounding tissue. She told me she wanted a mammogram immediatley and was going to contact my gp. I was taken to mammo and did one with 3 different angles of each breast. The Dr. came in afterward and told me she wants to biopsy both the lump and a lymph node (when she talked about the lymph node she mentioned staging purposes). She also kept asking me if I was sure I had no history of breast cancer.She said I would have my results the day after my biopsy and asked if she would rather I have her or my gp call with results and course of treatment.  When I went in that day I was just concerned how long it would take because I had someone covering for me at work that couldn't stay long, by the time I left I was scared out of my mind. If she seriously thought it was cancer wouldn't she have told me? The only thing she would tell me is that my other breast is perfectly normal. She looked kind of panicked or uncomfortable or something, it realy put me at unease. Any thoughts on any of this?  I'd appreciate anything. Posts.Title: 15 minutes and counting 33skidoo meima-Bev

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 03:08AM irish22 wrote: ((Jenn)) I think we all know what you're feeling. It seems so surreal to almost mourn your own life while you're still alive. It's almost like I've passed to a purgatory of sorts, I live in two separate worlds these days. I can't seem to find a happy medium in what I expect from people. I don't want to be fawned over and treated with sympathy but I don't want people to expect me to be the person I used to be and that I will likely never feel as physically well as I once did.  I live a pretty normal life besides docs and meds at bedtime. I go out with friends, I shop, I get pedicures and I work. I doubt anyone on the street would ever guess I have cancer which sometimes infuriates me. I see these people going about their own lives and business and I think how unfair it is that I can do what they do but I do it with this life sentence of suck hanging over my head at all times. I get pissed when people complain about their trivial problems like it's the end of the world and I often get snarky with them about how things could be worse. When I hear someone in public complaining about something stupid I have an urge to just walk up to them and say "Excuse me, you think that's a problem? I have terminal cancer. That's a problem." I long for the days when my biggest issues was getting stuck working two weekends in a row. I get pissed explaining about my cancer over and over. No I'm not cured yet. Yes I still have cancer. Yes I will always have cancer. Some days I feel like they're disappointed this whole ordeal isn't more eventful or I wonder if they think I'm lying since I'm doing well right now. There is nothing fair about any of this.Maybe in another life we could have been the semi-insensitive and ignorant bystanders, but in this life this is where we are. Just know that you are never alone in this.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 11:04PM irish22 wrote: I had them do a bone scan, breast MRI and PET/CT right away. The surgeon I was recommended too after dx was kind enough to set them up and I had them done in less then a week after my dx. Ask when you get them done for copies of discs or slides to take with you (I suggest two sets, one to give to your team and one to keep for your self incase med recs or a doc loses them which happened to me right away). Also get copies of reports from each scan for your self to keep in own records and one set faxed to your new doc or onc handling case. While for the most part all docs i've met have been great I also work in healthcare and know that I need to be my own advocate as well. Good luck and God Bless on your journey. I hope you will find this board to be a source of strengh, compassion and knowledge like I have. <3
